bibl.title: Letter from Wyndham B. Blanton to Laura Armistead Carter, June 21, 1929

div1.p: Blanton asks for information regarding mosquitoes and yellow fever epidemics in Virginia for his research on the history of medicine in Virginia.

div1.head: Letter from Wyndham B. Blanton to Laura Armistead Carter, June 21, 1929
div1.opener:
Misel
History of Medecine in Va.
WYNDHAM B. BLANTON, M. D.
828 WEST FRANKLIN STREET
RICHMOND, VIRGINIA
June 21, 1929.
Miss L. A. Carter,
Westmoreland,
2122 California Street,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
At Doctor Williams' suggestion,
I am writing you. We are preparing a history of
medicine in Virginia and I understand that you have
in hand the manuscript of your father's book on the
history of yellow fever. We are anxious for the
following data:

list.item:
1. The number, date, duration and severity of epi-
demics of yellow fever in Virginia.

3. How yellow fever reached the colony in the 17th
century when travel by sea was as slow as it was.

4. Whether the stegomyia fasciata was indigenous to
Virginia or was brought here on sailing vessels.

div1.p:
I wonder if you can give me this informa-
tion or cite me to any literature.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Wyndham B. Blanton. Wyndham B. Blanton.
WBB/McR
